title: POLITICO Playbook PM: Trump’s world of political pain
text:
POLITICO Playbook PM: Trump’s world of political pain Presented by

President Donald Trump listens during a meeting in the Oval Office on Tuesday, April 10. | Evan Vucci/AP Photo

THE PRESIDENT’S WORLD …

-- RUDY GIULIANI has had two bad stories in two days. Wednesday: Bloomberg revealed that President DONALD TRUMP urged then-Secretary of State REX TILLERSON to help one of Giuliani’s clients. Today: Two of the men who worked with Rudy on Ukraine were indicted.

-- TURKEY -- a NATO ally -- has essentially gone rogue in the Middle East, invading Syria to fight the Kurds, ignoring the dire warnings of U.S. policymakers and the U.S. military. TRUMP’S response to the Kurds, which helped America battle ISIS for years: Fend for yourself. Veteran Rep. John Shimkus (R-Ill.) says he’s no longer supporting Trump after he abandoned the Kurds. Shimkus is not running for reelection

-- DEMOCRATS are moving steadily toward impeachment.

-- CHINA is in town for trade negotiations, and it’s far from clear a deal will be reached in this round.

-- HIS POLL NUMBERS ARE TANKING, and he’s lashing out at the professional pollsters at Fox News. (See FiveThirtyEight’s presidential approval tracker.)

BREAKING IT ALL DOWN:

-- RUDY’S MESS: WSJ: “Two Foreign-Born Men Who Helped Giuliani on Ukraine Arrested on Campaign-Finance Charges,” by Aruna Viswanatha, Rebecca Ballhaus and Sadie Gurman: “Two foreign-born donors to a pro- Trump fundraising committee who helped Rudy Giuliani’s efforts to investigate Democrat Joe Biden were arrested late Wednesday on criminal charges of violating campaign finance rules and are expected to appear in court on Thursday, according to people familiar with the matter.

“Lev Parnas and Igor Fruman, two Florida businessmen, have been under investigation by the U.S. Attorney’s office in Manhattan, and are expected to appear in federal court in Virginia later on Thursday, the people said. The men’s nationalities was unclear, though both were believed to have been born in former Soviet republics. … The exact nature of the charges couldn’t immediately be determined.” WSJ … The indictment

-- ANOTHER D.C. ANGLE: The indictment says Parnas and Fruman committed to raising $20,000 or more in 2018 for a “then-sitting U.S. Congressman,” whom they also sought help in removing the U.S. ambassador to Ukraine. Fruman also donated $2,700 to this congressman, and gave in Parnas’ name. Fruman and Parnas both donated to former Dallas-area GOP Rep. Pete Sessions, who is trying to mount a comeback bid in a Waco-based district.

-- ANDREW DESIDERIO (@desiderioDC): “BREAKING: House impeachment investigators have subpoenaed Giuliani associates Lev Parnas and Igor Fruman.” The letter … They probably won’t come, and will say they are under indictment.

-- DO YOU WONDER WHY so few Hill Republicans are defending the president? Because they don’t know what is coming -- ever. This episode is a perfect example.

ANOTHER BIG WSJ SCOOP -- “White House Shifted Authority Over Ukraine Aid Amid Legal Concerns,” by Andrew Duehren and Gordon Lubold: “The White House gave a politically appointed official the authority to keep aid to Ukraine on hold after career budget staff members questioned the legality of delaying the funds, according to people familiar with the matter, a shift that House Democrats are probing in their impeachment inquiry. …

“While career civil servants put an initial hold on the aid, Michael Duffey, associate director of national security programs in OMB, was given the authority for continuing to keep the aid on hold after the career staff began raising their concerns to political officials at OMB, according to the people familiar with the matter. Mr. Duffey also began overseeing the process for approving and releasing funds, called apportionment, for other foreign aid and defense accounts, according to a public document indicating the change.” WSJ

SYRIA LATEST … NYT’S CARLOTTA GALL in Akcakale, Turkey, and PATRICK KINGSLEY in Istanbul: “Kurdish-Led Militia Casualties Climb as Turkey’s Syria Offensive Continues”: “Shells and rockets landed in the center of this busy Turkish border town early Thursday afternoon, killing two civilians, one of them an infant, and wounding 46, in a sharp escalation of the conflict between the Turkish state and the Kurdish militias who fought alongside American forces in the campaign to contain Islamist extremists in northern Syria.” NYT

-- @realDonaldTrump at 9:27 a.m.: “Turkey has been planning to attack the Kurds for a long time. They have been fighting forever. We have no soldiers or Military anywhere near the attack area. I am trying to end the ENDLESS WARS. Talking to both sides. Some want us to send tens of thousands of soldiers to....” … “....the area and start a new war all over again. Turkey is a member of NATO. Others say STAY OUT, let the Kurds fight their own battles (even with our financial help). I say hit Turkey very hard financially & with sanctions if they don’t play by the rules! I am watching closely.”

Good Thursday afternoon. PUBLISHING NOTE: Playbook PM will be off on Monday due to the holiday. The morning edition of Playbook will still publish.

THE WASHINGTON MYSTICS have one more chance to secure the franchise’s first WNBA title when they host the Connecticut Sun tonight for a decisive Game 5. Tipoff is at 8 p.m. on ESPN2. Go Mystics!

HOUSE APPROPRIATIONS CHAIRWOMAN NITA LOWEY (D-N.Y.) is retiring. She is 82. Lowey’s statement

IMPEACHMENT CLIP PACKET -- “Trump adviser says China provided information about Hunter Biden,” by Financial Times’ Demetri Sevastopulo: “Michael Pillsbury, an informal White House adviser on China, said he received information about the business activities of Hunter Biden during a visit to Beijing in the same week Donald Trump urged China to probe the son of Joe Biden. …

“‘I got a quite a bit of background on Hunter Biden from the Chinese,’ Mr. Pillsbury told the Financial Times. Mr Pillsbury’s comments to the FT came after he revealed on Fox Business that he had raised the issue of the Bidens during a visit to China a week ago. … Mr. Pillsbury declined to say whether he was asked to raise the issue by the president.” FT

-- SCHIFF THROWS SHADE … SAN FRANCISCO CHRONICLE’S TAL KOPAN: “The prominence of the impeachment inquiry has brought an outsized glare from Republicans. … [House Intel Chairman Adam] Schiff brushes off the attacks, saying [House Minority Leader Kevin] McCarthy has ‘no independent judgment’ outside of the president and that Trump is simply goading him out of desperation.

“‘I do my best to tune them out,’ Schiff said. ‘The president needs an adversary, and he would like nothing better than for me to engage him.’” SF Chronicle

-- “Anti-Trump group launches $1 million in swing-state impeachment ads,” by Maggie Severns: “The Democratic-aligned digital group ACRONYM is launching a $1 million ad campaign in five swing states focused on impeaching President Donald Trump, answering a barrage of ads from Trump and allies condemning Democrats over the impeachment push.

“Officials for the nonprofit described the $1 million campaign as a large-scale testing effort to see how to best persuade voters to support impeaching the president. … The campaign will begin in five states with 2020 electoral votes up for grabs: Arizona, Michigan, North Carolina, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin. But after the initial run, ACRONYM will consider expanding the spending into a bigger national campaign.” POLITICO

TRADE WARS -- THE PRESIDENT TWEETS at 9:49 a.m.: “Big day of negotiations with China. They want to make a deal, but do I? I meet with the Vice Premier tomorrow at The White House.”

-- ADAM BEHSUDI on the CHINA DEAL: “How a U.S.-China trade deal could get more complicated”: “Human rights sanctions and fallout from raging unrest in Hong Kong would have made a banner week for U.S.-China relations under any circumstances. Now throw in high-stakes trade negotiations as the two countries stand on the brink of another round of tariff escalation that could further rattle the global economy. …

“It's still unclear whether the two sides will be able to agree on confidence-building measures that would halt additional tariff escalation. The Chinese were hoping to get a reprieve on an Oct. 15 tariff increase, but one person close to the talks said that a delay is unlikely to happen based on what China has offered so far.” POLITICO

-- “‘An existential political risk’: Trump manufactures a swing-state problem,” by Ben White: “Donald Trump shocked the world and won the White House in 2016 on bold promises to bring greatness back to the industrial Midwest. But his promise now faces a brutal reality: The U.S. manufacturing sector is spiraling into recession, victimized by Trump’s trade wars and sagging confidence among corporate executives who have little idea how to plan for an uncertain economic future.

“Unless Trump can ram his revised North American Free Trade Agreement through Congress and cut a deal with the Chinese to erase historically high tariffs, he may find it difficult to repeat wins in states like Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania that drove him into office in 2016 by the narrowest of margins.” POLITICO

THE LATEST ON HONG KONG -- “Apple, Google Pull Hong Kong Protest Apps After China Uproar,” by WSJ’s Tripp Mickle, Jeff Horwitz and Yoko Kubota: “Apple removed from its App Store a crowdsourced map service that allows Hong Kong protesters to track police activity, one day after the Chinese Communist Party-run People’s Daily newspaper lashed out at the iPhone maker, calling the app ‘toxic software.’ …

“Separately, Alphabet Inc.’s Google unit removed from its Google Play store a mobile game that allowed players to role-play as a Hong Kong protester. … The swift removal of apps Beijing finds objectionable will likely help lower the two tech giants’ risk of running afoul of the Chinese government and upsetting consumers in the country. But it could also subject them to criticism in the West that they are siding with Beijing in the contentious debate over Hong Kong’s future.” WSJ

THE TRUMP ADMINISTRATION -- “For the first time in decades, EPA is overhauling how communities must test for lead in water”

RIPPLE EFFECT -- “Parkland and Sante Fe schools disclose devastating after-effects of shootings,” by Nicole Gaudiano: “Substance abuse and mental health problems surged following last year’s deadly mass shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., while test scores tanked. More kids are said to be anxious, depressed and cutting school. In Santa Fe, Texas, where eight students and two teachers were killed in May of last year, it’s a similar story, according to documents obtained by POLITICO.

“A growing number of students need support from mental health professionals, and more police and security officers have been called in to cope with increased student misconduct. The devastating turn in mental health, academic performance and substance abuse is revealed in a series of federal aid applications from these school districts. The documents paint the most detailed picture of what really happens to a school after a mass shooting.” POLITICO

2020 WATCH -- “For Bernie Sanders, His Most Trusted Adviser Is Married to Him,” by NYT’s Sydney Ember and Jonathan Martin in Burlington, Vt.: “It was [Jane] Sanders who provided a medical update after her husband was hospitalized in Las Vegas last week and had two stents inserted into an artery — issuing a statement and speaking to reporters outside the hospital. When doctors confirmed to her on Thursday that Mr. Sanders had suffered a heart attack, she said, it was her decision to wait until he was discharged the next day to release that information. …

“Ms. Sanders has played a central role in her husband’s political life for decades, acting as his confidante and his closest adviser. Yet as Mr. Sanders weighs the future of his candidacy, never has it been clearer that the two of them are primarily making the calls for his campaign. … In a rare interview on Wednesday at their home in Burlington, Ms. Sanders said it would be ‘egotistical’ to call herself Mr. Sanders’s top adviser but allowed that she was ‘very much a close adviser.’” NYT

-- “Political Campaigns Know Where You’ve Been. They’re Tracking Your Phone,” by WSJ’s Sam Schechner, Emily Glazer and Patience Haggin: “Armed with this data, campaigns can track down and segment potential voters based on apps they use and places they have been, including rallies, churches and gun clubs. In some cases, voters might see an ad on their mobile phone. In others, companies can match data to a specific person, allowing campaigns to determine who gets a fundraising call or a knock on the door.

“Last September, the campaign of then-Senate candidate Beto O’Rourke was able to identify some attendees’ mobile device ID numbers during a rally with musician Willie Nelson. A company collected the unique ID numbers of phones that pinged their location while at the event, according to people familiar with the Senate campaign. The company, working with an O’Rourke campaign consulting firm, then matched some of those IDs with contact information, such as email addresses.” WSJ

THE POLICY PRIMARY -- “How Cory Booker would help college athletes get paid,” by Bianca Quilantan: “The New Jersey senator’s plan builds on legislation recently passed in California, which will permit student athletes to receive payment for the use of their likenesses by 2023. In addition, Booker is in favor of closing the gender gap in college sports, giving student athletes more medical coverage and increasing federal funding for states to improve recreation facilities.” POLITICO

CLIMATE FILES -- “The world needs a massive carbon tax in just 10 years to limit climate change, IMF says,” by WaPo’s Chris Mooney and Andrew Freedman: “A global agreement to make fossil fuel burning more expensive is urgent and the most efficient way of fighting climate change, an International Monetary Fund study found on Thursday.

“The group found that a global tax of $75 per ton by the year 2030 could limit the planet’s warming to 2 degrees Celsius (3.6 degrees Fahrenheit), or roughly double what it is now. That would greatly increase the price of fossil fuel-based energy — especially from the burning of coal — but the economic disruption could be offset by routing the money raised straight back to citizens.” WaPo … The report

MEDIAWATCH -- “How A.G. Sulzberger Is Leading the New York Times Into the Future,” by Time’s Karl Vick

-- “Splinter News Shutting Down,” by The Daily Beast’s Maxwell Tani: “In an internal memo sent Tuesday to staff, Paul Maidment, the editorial director of Splinter’s parent company G/O Media, praised the site’s journalism, but said the publication struggled to gain large numbers of readers.” Daily Beast

TRANSITIONS -- “Deval Patrick joins Higher Ground Labs,” by Stephanie Murray: “Former Massachusetts Gov. Deval Patrick is joining the advisory board of Higher Ground Labs, an accelerator and venture capital firm for startups that sell technology to progressive campaigns and causes. … Patrick will serve as an honorary member on the incubator’s advisory board.”

-- Brooke Oberwetter is now head of community affairs at Amazon. She previously was manager of public policy at Facebook.

BONUS BIRTHDAYS: Laurence Tribe, the Carl M. Loeb professor at Harvard Law School, is 78 … Matti Friedman, NYT contributing opinion writer, is 42
